What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about human and child development as a whole. Took a lot from the weekly readings as well
I learned effective strategies for engaging with kids to increase wonder and read scientific literature on this topic. Also we learned how to write concisely in a supportive environment.

Wide selection of developmental psychology literature on child wonder, curiosity, play and learning. Some content on construction of scientific knowledge, dealing with disinformation towards the end of the course. Presentation skills, case studies, synthesizing and applying readings.

What I learned in this class was split into two sections.

Readings: Our readings gave a comprehensive overlook of wonder in infants and children, as well as a look into the elements that underlie wonder in all ages. We read about abstract concepts, mechanistic vs. functional explanations, history of science, open-ended questions, and scientific misinformation. This is just a brief summary of some of the topics we covered.
Class: I really enjoyed class, because it was a fun mix of reading overviews and our professor's experience with science education. Some classes were spent more on reading topics. Other classes were more anecdotal. We would listen to Professor Keil's personal accounts of wonder, and share our own opinions on generational differences in science education. Each class also had breakout rooms, kindly facilitated by a graduate student's thought experiments.

We also each did one "wonder presentation," and I can say with confidence that I will not forget the research I did for my wonder. I have an in depth understanding of my topic, as well as some knowledge from other students' presentations.

I learned how to communicate with people in a way that promotes wonder more. Mostly this consists of asking questions and supporting interests that people raise. It's been especially good for talking to little kids.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths are that Prof. Keil is very knowledgeable and passionate about teaching the information that the class is very engaging

I liked the format and the weekly writing assignment, but I thought some of the discussions could be more engaging. Perhaps this was a limitation of zoom learning. I loved the wonder assignment and the final project!
Excellent instruction and selection of readings was very strong, provocative and relevant
The wonder presentations were certainly a highlight, the range of interests in the class varied widely and I learned so many new things.

Strengths: 
Casual atmosphere geared towards learning and not grades; short presentations to break up the class; brief break-out room discussions (amazing thought experiments courtesy of our business grad student!)
I loved the homework system. We usually had 2-3 readings to do, coupled with a reading response to be turned in once a week. The reading response was limited to 200 words and was meant to be in response to a specific question. Professor Keil's reading response prompts were novel and forced us to think outside of the box. In all honesty, this is the only class where I consistently 'deep-read' my readings. I wanted to have a good grasp of the papers' arguments to better generate my own answer and not simply summarize. Writing succinctly is a skill in and of itself, and I'm thankful that responses were formatted this way. They made the coursework more engaging.

Weaknesses:
Some days we spent a bit more time on anecdotes than I would have liked, but this is not to say that I didn't enjoy the more anecdotal days. If anything, I was more excited about the reading topics for those lessons and wanted to dissect them more.

Each unit (basically 1/week) varies in terms of how accessible, interesting, and functionally applicable it is. You learn some cool and interesting things from a professor who is really passionate about the material, but the pace can feel fast and slow at the wrong times because of the variation with topics. You essentially learn two-three big ideas that are reinforced throughout. So, on the bright side, you know a few interesting and applicable things really well, and on the other hand, you don't know that many things.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Live seminars helped keep course interesting
I think having some more structure could serve the course well, such as coming up with certain topics to have students present, so that the material we are covering is more engaging.

More breakout groups, it sometimes felt difficult to participate in large group discussion because of the logistics of zoom (raising hands, multiple people wanting to contribute at the same time etc.)

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, absolutely recommend with Prof. Keil. Class is a gem

Yes, if you are thinking of going into child education. This was a cool topic that I think will be a fun in-person class with fun assignments, and it felt like we were learning for the sake of learning rather than for the grade.
Absolutely
Yes!!!!! One of a kind course with fascinating material

I would! My friends seemed equally curious about this class as I was. They often came to me with bizarre processes or concepts that they didn't understand, and told me to bring them up in class :)
I never once felt academically overwhelmed (in the grade-specific way students often are); it was a calm and casual atmosphere. If you're okay with this more slow-going vibe, this class if for you. You'll be learning about learning curiosities, so anyone who is interested in childhood education or about their own waning academic wonder (like me), will enjoy Childhood Wonder. If you're a non-cogsci/psych major, I get the sense that you would manage the topics pretty well. Though it's always helpful to have some background to further bolster your understanding.
Only if you are fascinated by the material and plan to actually do all the reading.

You have to realize that the professor is really nice and only cares about you being interested and passionate. Though he seems old school and all of the writing and reading responses (and, tbh, dryness) might make you feel like the class is more intense than it is, really just take it to enjoy a few good lessons with some good subjects, and fun and relevant project, and a not difficult paper.
